{{Short description|American on-air radio personality (born 1980)}} {{use mdy dates|date=April 2022}} {{Infobox person | name = Bobby Bones | image = Bobby Bones - iHeartRadio Theater.jpg | caption = Bones at the iHeartRadio Theater in NYC, for Brad Paisley's album release party. | birth_name = Bobby Estell | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1980|4|2|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Mountain Pine, Arkansas]], U.S. | education = | alma_mater = [[Henderson State University]] | othername = | occupation = Radio personality, television personality, author, comedian, musician | height = 6ft{{Cite web|url=https://bobbybones.iheart.com/featured/bobby-bones/content/2019-10-13-bobby-officially-measured-in-studio-to-get-internet-height-changed/|title=Bobby Officially Measured In Studio To Get Internet Height Changed | The Bobby Bones Show|website=The Bobby Bones Show}} | spouse = {{marriage| Caitlin Parker |2021}} | module = {{Infobox musical artist | embed = yes | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | instrument = Vocals | label = [[Black River Entertainment|Black River]] }} }} '''Bobby Bones''' (born '''Bobby Estell;''' April 2, 1980){{cite news|url= https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2014/12/21/bobby-bones/20607287/| title=Radio host Bobby Bones still feels pain of mom's addiction, death|work=[[The Tennessean]]|location=Nashville, Tennessee| first=Brad |last=Schmitt|date=December 20, 2014|access-date=November 20, 2018 |quote=Born in Hot Springs, Ark., as Bobby Estell (a radio programmer named him "Bobby Bones" early in Bones' career)}} is an American radio and television personality, best known for hosting the nationally syndicated ''[[The Bobby Bones Show]]'', originating from the iHeart Studios in [[Nashville, TN]], and for his role as a full-time mentor on ''[[American Idol]]'' on ABC. He was the winner of season 27 of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]'' with partner [[Sharna Burgess]]. He has also written two [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' best sellers]]. Bones has also released a number of [[country music]] albums through [[Black River Entertainment]]. ==Early life and education== Bones was born in [[Hot Springs, Arkansas]], on April 2, 1980, and raised in the small community of [[Mountain Pine, Arkansas]]. He has said his mother became pregnant with him at age 15, when his father was 17.{{cite AV media |people=Bobby Bones |date=May 19, 2016 |title=The Bobby Bones Show |medium=radio broadcast |url=http://www.iheart.com/show/139-Bobby-Bones-Show/ |access-date=May 19, 2016 |publisher=iHeartMedia }} He was raised by his mother and maternal grandmother. His biological father was with him until the age of five, but then left the family.{{cite web | title =Bobby Bones may be Regis & Kelly co-host | publisher =KXAN | date =January 13, 2011 | url =https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yLk8orZDCsg | access-date =June 25, 2014 }} Bones began dreaming of a radio career around the age of 5. His mother died at age 49 after battling addiction problems in 2014.{{cite news | last =Shea| first =Stewart | title =Mountain Pine native deals real on the radio, goes nationwide| newspaper =[[Arkansas Democrat-Gazette]]|via=Arkansas Online| date =March 23, 2014|archive-date=September 17, 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180917105251/https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2014/mar/23/mountain-pine-native-deals-real-radio-goes-nationw/?f=trilakes| url =http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2014/mar/23/mountain-pine-native-deals-real-radio-goes-nationw/?f=trilakes| access-date =June 4, 2014}} He grew up poor, and often viewed radio as a way of escaping [[poverty]]. Bones began his radio career at age 17 at the campus station of [[Henderson State University]], [[KSWH-LP|KSWH-FM]] "The Pulse". He graduated with a B.A. in Radio/Television from Henderson in 2002.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} ==Career== While still in college, Bones went to work as a station hand at [[KLAZ]] in Hot Springs, Arkansas, but was put on the air within a few days of being hired. A manager there gave him the choice of going on the air as Bobby Z or Bobby Bones of which he chose the latter. Bones' first full-time radio contract paid him $17,000. In 2002, Bones was hired by Q100/KQAR in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]]. He then worked for radio station ([[KLAL]]), which led to his hosting ''The Bobby Bones Show'' on [[KHFI-FM]] in [[Austin, Texas]]. According to ''The Washington Post'', Bones is different from typical radio DJs, as he doesn't have the "classic, booming radio DJ voice".{{cite news | last =Yar | first =Emily | title =Bobby Bones, new to WMZQ, hosts a different kind of country music morning radio show | newspaper =The Washington Post | date =March 18, 2013 | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/bobby-bones-new-to-wmzq-hosts-a-different-kind-of-country-music-morning-radio-show/2014/03/18/3d9fe638-aec5-11e3-9627-c65021d6d572_story.html | access-date =June 28, 2014}} Despite being commonly referred to as such Bones does not refer to himself as a DJ. ===Austin=== Bones was originally hired for the evening shift on KHFI-FM and was soon moved to mornings. While in Austin, he met two of his future co-hosts, Lunchbox (in a bar) and Amy (in a Culver's). Bones believed in Amy and put her on the air immediately.{{cite web | last =Shea | first =Stewart | title =Country Radio's New Voice | work =Arkansas Online | date =March 11, 2014 | url =http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2014/mar/11/country-radios-new-voice/?print | access-date =June 11, 2014 }} His executive producer at the time, Alayna Messer, was previously an intern on the show. Over ten years, the show built its audience into the top-rated morning show in Austin{{cite web | last =Dinges | first =Gary | title =Bobby Bones Austin's Top Morning Host | publisher =Austin 360 | date =October 9, 2013 | url =http://www.austin360.com/weblogs/tv-radio-blog/2013/oct/09/radio-ratings-bobby-bones-austins-top-morning-host/ | access-date =June 10, 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141205053425/http://www.austin360.com/weblogs/tv-radio-blog/2013/oct/09/radio-ratings-bobby-bones-austins-top-morning-host/ | url-status =dead | archive-date =December 5, 2014}} and was syndicated in a few regional markets. At the height of his popularity, Bones was offered a job outside of radio but ultimately chose to remain with Clear Channel (now iHeart Media). ===Nashville=== In 2012, [[Clear Channel Communications|Clear Channel]] moved Bones and his show from Austin with its Top 40 format to [[Nashville]] and a country music format while taking ''The Bobby Bones Show'' nationwide. Bones took over the slot hosted by longtime DJ [[Gerry House]],{{cite web | title =Air talent is radio's new country crossover | publisher =Inside Radio | url =http://www.insideradio.com/Article.asp?id=2613255&spid=32061 | access-date =June 29, 2014 | archive-url = https://archive.today/20140702122632/http://www.insideradio.com/Article.asp?id=2613255&spid=32061 | url-status =dead | archive-date =July 2, 2014}} who retired in 2010. Bones now broadcasts from the WSIX-FM studios in Nashville on weekday mornings from 5:00 a.m. to 10 a.m. (CT). His co-host is Amy, and features Producer Eddie, Lunchbox, Raymundo, Morgan Number 2, Mike D., Abby, and Scuba Steve. The Bobby Bones Show has become a regular interview stop for top country music stars and even artists/celebrities outside the genre of country.{{cite web | title =The Bobby Bones Show | url =http://www.bobbybones.com/main.html | access-date =June 28, 2014 }} [[Luke Bryan]], John Mayer, [[Taylor Swift]], Garth Brooks, Ed Sheeran, [[Blake Shelton]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Lady Antebellum]], [[Jason Aldean]], [[Dierks Bentley]], and more have been featured in interviews on the morning show. ===Syndication=== In February 2013, ''The Bobby Bones Show'' was nationally syndicated through iHeart Media-owned [[Premiere Networks]]{{cite web | title =Bobby Bones Shifts From Top 40 To Country, Launching Daily National Country Show And Weekend Countdown Show | date =February 23, 2013 | url =http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/114921/bobby-bones-shifts-from-top-40-to-country-launchin | access-date =June 29, 2014 }} and was made available via [[iHeartRadio.com]] and the iHeartRadio mobile app. The show is currently heard on more than 150 radio stations in the U.S., Canada, and UK.{{cite web | title =Bobby Bones Show Affiliates | url =http://www.bobbybones.com/pages/affiliates_ct30.html | access-date =June 28, 2014 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140707185015/http://www.bobbybones.com/pages/affiliates_ct30.html | archive-date =July 7, 2014 | url-status =dead }} ''The Bobby Bones Show'' has an estimated audience of nearly 9.2 million listeners a week. Bones also hosts the weekly “Country Top 30 with Bobby Bones,” carried on over 100 radio stations nationwide.{{cite web | title =Country Top 30 with Bobby Bones | url =http://www.bobbybones.com/charts/country-top-30-with-bobby-bones-144/ | access-date =June 28, 2014 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20141110114009/http://www.bobbybones.com/charts/country-top-30-with-bobby-bones-144/ | archive-date =November 10, 2014 | url-status =dead }} As part of the iHeart Media family, Bones has been tapped to host, present, and even perform at the annual [[iHeartRadio Country Festival]] held in Austin, Texas, iHeartRadio Music Festival held in Las Vegas, Nevada and the annual [[iHeartRadio Music Awards]] in Los Angeles, California.{{cite web | title =Bobby Presents at iHeart Radio Awards | date =May 1, 2014 | url =http://www.bobbybones.com/articles/what-we-talked-about-457650/bobby-presents-at-iheartradio-awards-12310709/ | access-date =June 28, 2014 | archive-url = https://archive.today/20140702122637/http://www.bobbybones.com/articles/what-we-talked-about-457650/bobby-presents-at-iheartradio-awards-12310709/ | url-status =dead | archive-date =July 2, 2014}} ===Accidental trigger of Emergency Alert System === In October 2014, Bones accidentally triggered the [[Emergency Alert System]] by playing EAS tones during an on-air rant about an erroneous EAS test interrupting coverage locally of the [[2014 World Series]] on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] affiliate [[WZTV]]. The EAS tones would have only triggered the EAS issuance in Nashville, but since the show was in syndication, the signal cascaded through the show's nationwide affiliates, and caused [[AT&T U-verse]] boxes nationwide to lock up with the erroneous test.{{Cite web |url=http://www.wkrn.com/story/26886059/glitch-on-bobby-bones-show-may-have-caused-u-verse-error |title=Glitch on Bobby Bones show may have caused U-verse error - WKRN News 2 |access-date=October 27, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027153258/http://www.wkrn.com/story/26886059/glitch-on-bobby-bones-show-may-have-caused-u-verse-error |archive-date=October 27, 2014 |url-status=dead }} In May 2015, Bones's employer iHeartMedia paid a $1 million FCC fine due to the incident and removed all EAS sound effects from their nationwide sound library to prevent a recurrence.{{cite web|url=https://www.fcc.gov/document/iheart-pay-1m-misusing-eas-tones-during-bobby-bones-show|title=iHeart to Pay $1M for Misusing EAS Tones During The Bobby Bones Show|date=December 9, 2015}} ==Other media== Bones appeared in the 2009 feature film, ''[[Bandslam]]'', with [[Vanessa Hudgens]]. He has also appeared on the ABC drama [[Nashville (2012 TV series)|''Nashville'']] and has been a guest host with [[Kelly Ripa]] on ''[[Live! with Regis and Kelly]]''.{{cite web | title =Bobby Bones on Regis and Kelly | date =January 28, 2011 | url =https://wiki24x7.com/who-is-bobby-bones-bio-age-wiki-wife-and-net-worth/ | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20211018103501/https://wiki24x7.com/who-is-bobby-bones-bio-age-wiki-wife-and-net-worth/ | url-status =dead | archive-date =October 18, 2021 | access-date =July 1, 2014 }} In 2012 Bones was part of the Fox Sports Radio lineup, hosting the weekend sports talk program ''Roddick and Bones'' with tennis star [[Andy Roddick]], airing Saturdays from 1:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. Eastern Time on nearly 300 radio stations.{{cite web | title =Andy Roddick Fox Sports Live Host | date =May 22, 2013 | url =https://www.si.com/more-sports/2013/05/22/andy-roddick-fox-sports-live-host | access-date = June 29, 2014 }} Bones is also the host of the podcast “The Bobbycast” where he interviews singers/songwriters of all genres{{Cite web |title=Bobbycast with Ben Rector |url=https://www.iheart.com/podcast/139-bobby-cast-27722337/episode/333-ben-rector-on-92785800/?cmp=ios_share&sc=ios_social_share&pr=false}} which The Washington Post dubbed as a "treasure trove of unusually candid anecdotes."{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/how-does-country-music-really-work-bobby-boness-podcast-is-an-unlikely-gold-mine-of-insider-info/2017/02/09/46c2dc44-ee22-11e6-9973-c5efb7ccfb0d_story.html|title=How does country music really work? Bobby Bones's podcast is an unlikely gold mine of insider info.|last=Yahr|first=Emily|date=February 9, 2017|newspaper=The Washington Post}} He has also launched his own podcast network, the Nashville Podcast Network.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} On May 17, 2016, he released his first book entitled ''Bare Bones, I'm Not Lonely If You're Reading This Book.''[http://www.today.com/video/country-radio-host-bobby-bones-reveals-how-he-got-his-name-688002115765 "Country radio host Bobby Bones reveals how he got his name"] today.com, May 18, 2016 In 2018, Bones was a guest mentor for [[American Idol (season 16)|season sixteen]] of ''[[American Idol]]'' (the first to air on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]) during the top 24 round. On November 6, 2018, it was announced Bones would become a full-time mentor for the series beginning in [[American Idol (season 17)|season seventeen]].{{Cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/11/american-idol-bobby-bones-mentor-abc-katy-perry-luke-bryan-lionel-richie-ryan-seacrest-1202496596/|title='American Idol' Sets Bobby Bones As Official In-House Mentor|last=Ramos|first=Dino-Ray|date=November 6, 2018|website=Deadline|language=en|access-date=April 9, 2019}} During an episode which aired April 8, 2019, Bones served as guest host, as host [[Ryan Seacrest]] was sick and missed the taping.{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2019/04/08/american-idol-ryan-seacrest-sick-bobby-bones-host/3398073002/|title='American Idol': Bobby Bones steps in for ailing Ryan Seacrest on Monday's episode|website=USA Today|language=en|access-date=April 9, 2019}} In June 2019, Bones filmed an episode of [[Running Wild With Bear Grylls]] in Norway. The episode aired on January 14, 2020.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/running-wild-with-bear-grylls/s05/e09|title=Running Wild With Bear Grylls - Season 5 Episode 9|via=www.rottentomatoes.com}} He was a judge of [[Topgolf]]'s original series ''Who Will Rock You''. He signed an overall deal with BBC Studios.{{Cite web|date=October 29, 2020|title=Bobby Bones Signs Overall TV Development Deal With BBC Studios' L.A. Production Arm|url=https://musicrow.com/2020/10/bobby-bones-signs-overall-tv-development-deal-with-bbc-studios-l-a-production-arm/|access-date=October 30, 2020|language=en}} ''Breaking Bobby Bones'', on the [[National Geographic Channel]] began airing in 2021. In each episode, Bones meets a real person doing a "real" job or sport, works with them to learn how to do it, and is critiqued on his performance. At the end of each episode, Bones does something special for week's guest that will improve their life, or help them with their career or other goals.{{citation needed|date=January 2022}} On December 31, 2021, Bones, along with [[Rachel Smith]] of ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'', hosted ''New Year's Eve Live: Nashville's Big Bash''. It was broadcast live from [[Nashville]] on [[CBS]].{{citation needed|date=January 2022}} In 2022, Bones hosted the [[USA Network]] competition series ''[[Snake in the Grass (TV series)|Snake in the Grass]]''.{{cite web|last=Gillette|first=Sam|title=Bobby Bones Is Learning to Be 'Vulnerable' with Wife Caitlin — and Challenging Himself on New Shows|url=https://people.com/tv/host-bobby-bones-is-challenging-himself/|website=[[People (magazine)|people]]|access-date=August 9, 2022|date=August 1, 2022}} ===''Dancing with the Stars''=== In September 2018, Bones was announced as one of the celebrities to compete on the [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 27)|27th season]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'', being paired with the professional dancer [[Sharna Burgess]]. {{green|30}} !style="background:gold;"|'''Winner''' |}{{Clear}} ==Personal life== On September 28, 2013, Bones and his crew were part of a team that set the Guinness World Record "Most hunger relief meals packaged in one hour (team)".{{cite web | title =Most Hunger Relief Meals Packaged in One Hour | work =Guinness Book of World Records | publisher =Guinness World Records | date =September 28, 2013 | url =http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/5000/most-hunger-relief-meals-packaged-in-one-hour-(team) | access-date =June 28, 2014 }} On August 5, 2015, during the [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign|2016 presidential campaign of Donald Trump]], Bones filed an "all purpose" [[Trademark|trademark application]] with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] for the rights to the phrase "[[Make America Great Again]]". Trump had registered the phrase for "political action committee services" but not for its use on hats, t-shirts, duffel bags, and other apparel and accessories that Bones now had the rights to. Two days later, on August 7, Bones tweeted, "hey @realDonaldTrump, if you donate 100k to @stjude, I will give you your clothing trademark back. thanks! – Bobby". Bones later tweeted an image on October 29 of a check from [[The Trump Organization]] for an undisclosed amount, stating it would go to [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]] and that Trump could "have [his] slogan back".{{Cite web |last=Morris |first=Chris |title=Donald Trump just got the rights to use slogan, 'Make America Great Again' Parker: 'I Get to Marry the Love of My Life'|website=PEOPLE.com}} ==Awards and honors== For four years running, from 2004 to 2008, Bones was named Best Radio Personality by the Austin Music Awards, presented by ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' and [[SXSW]]. The Bobby Bones Show also won Best Radio Program 2007–2008.{{cite news | title=Austin Music Awards | newspaper=Austin Chronicle | url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/Awards/MusicAwards/?mode=index | access-date=June 28, 2014}} On April 6, 2014, Bones, Amy, and Lunchbox won their first Academy of Country Music Award for National On-Air Personality of the Year, just nine months into Bones's first year in country music.{{cite web | title=Radio Award Winners Announced for the 49th Annual Academy of Country Music Awards | publisher=Academy of Country Music | date=February 18, 2014 | url=http://www.acmcountry.com/news.html?n_id=611 | access-date=June 28, 2014}} Bones became the youngest ever inductee into the [[National Radio Hall of Fame]] during a ceremony on November 2, 2017, at the [[Museum of Broadcast Communications]] in [[Chicago]].http://www.talkers.com June 26, 2017 The University of Arkansas awarded Bobby with an honorary doctorate at their Spring 2022 commencement ceremonies.{{cite web | url=https://news.uark.edu/articles/59843/bobby-bones-to-be-awarded-honorary-doctorate-at-commencement | title=Bobby Bones to be Awarded Honorary Doctorate at Commencement }} ==Bobby Bones and the Raging Idiots discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:14em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! colspan="4"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:9em;"| Sales |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]
